definition: A legal entity that is recognized as having rights and responsibilities distinct from its individual members, including corporations, partnerships, and other organizations that can enter into contracts, own property, and be subject to legal obligations as an artificial person under the law.
opposite_reasoning: NaturalPerson is the canonical legal and ontological complement to CorporatePerson. These two concepts partition the space of legal personhood in most legal systems: every person is either a natural person (human being) or a corporate person (legal entity). This complementary opposition provides maximum semantic distance within the personhood domain. For AI safety applications, this distinction is valuable for understanding: (1) attribution of responsibility (individual vs. organizational), (2) agency type (human vs. collective/artificial), and (3) legal vs. natural entities. The opposition is well-established in legal ontology and likely exists in both WordNet and SUMO, making it highly available and theoretically sound for Fisher-LDA steering.
